questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the green arrow in the image-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fossa of Rosenmuller

The image shown is the endoscopic view of the nasopharynx, and the marked structure is the Fossa of Rosenmuller. Fossa of Rosenmuller is a lateral pharyngeal recess that is present above and behind the torus tubarius. It is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch. On examination vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the nerve may be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

External Laryngeal  Nerve
Sol:  
a. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses and elongates the vocal cords, allowing high-pitch phonation.
Injury to this nerve → loss of ability to raise pitch, bowed vocal cord, and voice fatigue in singers.
b. Recurrent laryngeal nerve affects most intrinsic laryngeal muscles and leads to hoarseness, not isolated pitch loss.
c. Internal laryngeal nerve is sensory above the vocal cords.
d. Glossopharyngeal nerve is unrelated to vocal cord movement.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Upper airway examination
The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions-
1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction
2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space
3. Uses a cuff to protect the airway from secretions
4. Allows suction of secretions in impaired cough reflex
5. Allows administration of anesthesia

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with throat pain, fever and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
The tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis. The referred pain may be secondary to lesions or inflammatory processes of the nasopharynx, palatine tonsil, soft palate or posterior one third of the tongue.

questions.text: Following blast trauma a patient have tympanic membrane perforation, these findings are features of which level trauma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1 (Primary)
Sol:

questions.text: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection is most commonly associated with which tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Oropharyngeal carcinoma
Sol:  

• HPV, especially types 16 and 18, is strongly linked to oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, particularly tonsillar and base of tongue cancers.
• Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is usually associated with EBV (Epstein–Barr virus).
• Laryngeal and oral cavity carcinomas are mainly linked to tobacco and alcohol rather than HPV.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Total laryngectomy
The given image shows a post-operative stump created for breathing in patients undergoing total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma. In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx is removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

questions.text: Stapedial reflex is dependent on the integrity of which cranial nerve for its motor response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Facial nerve (CN VII)
Sol:  

Stapedial reflex (acoustic reflex):
Protects the inner ear from loud sounds by stapedius muscle contraction, which dampens stapes movement.
Pathway:
1. Sound → Cochlea → CN VIII (afferent)
2. Cochlear nucleus → Bilateral superior olivary complex → Facial nerve nucleus
3. CN VII (efferent) → Stapedius muscle contraction

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Type As curve
Sol:

questions.text: A child presenting with recurrent respiratory tract infection, mouth breathing and decreased hearing.On examination hypertrophy of adenoids was documented. Treatment On tympanometry which tympanogram will be seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type Flat tympanogram
Sol:  
• Child with recurrent URTI, mouth breathing, decreased hearing
• Hypertrophied adenoids → Obstruction of Eustachian tube → Otitis media with effusion (OME)
• Tympanometry findings in OME:
• Type B (Flat) tympanogram → Indicates middle ear fluid / effusion with no compliance peak

questions.text: 50 yrs old patient with history of fish intake present with some foreign body sensation.On examination it was stuck in pyriform sinus.Which nerve is at the high risk
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Internal Laryngeal Nerve 
Sol:  

• Foreign body in pyriform sinus is a common scenario with fish bone ingestion.
• The internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (from vagus nerve), runs beneath the mucosa of the pyriform fossa.
• It provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords and the pyriform fossa.
• Any instrumentation or trauma in this area can injure this nerve, leading to loss of sensation and risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

30-45 dB
A prediction of the air bone gap can be made using tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz:
A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates airbone gap of 20-30 dB.
A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 30-45 dB.
A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 45-60 dB.

questions.text: 9 yr old child present brought by his mother presents with hearing loss, mouth breathing and poor school performance.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Otitis Media With Effusion
Sol:  
Clinical features in the question:
6-year-old child
• Hearing loss → Conductive type
• Mouth breathing → Suggests adenoid hypertrophy
• Poor school performance → Often due to chronic hearing impairment
• No acute pain or fever → Not acute otitis media
Diagnosis:
• Otitis Media with Effusion (Glue Ear)
• Common in children due to Eustachian tube dysfunction
• Often associated with adenoid hypertrophy
• Presents with hearing loss, mouth breathing, poor scholastic performance, inattentiveness
• Tympanogram: Type B (Flat)

questions.text: Which of the following subunit is associated with inspiratory stridor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Supraglottic
Sol:

questions.text: 60 yrs old diabetic patient present with pain and blackish discoloration in the nose. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucomycosis
Sol:  
• 60-year-old diabetic patient (especially if uncontrolled or post-steroid/COVID)
• Blackish discoloration/necrosis of nasal mucosa
• These are classic signs of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, an angioinvasive fungal infection caused by Mucorales (Rhizopus, Mucor).

questions.text: Patient with history of fall is having blood in the ear, choose the most appropriate next investigation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CT
Sol:  
History of fall/head trauma
 Blood in the ear (Hemotympanum or Otorrhagia)
 This raises suspicion of:
 Temporal bone fracture (especially petrous part)
 Possible ossicular injury or CSF leak

questions.text: Uncinate process is superiorly attached to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Middle turbinate
Sol:  
Uncinate process
A thin curved bony process of the ethmoid bone forming part of the osteomeatal complex.
 Superior attachment: Lamina papyracea / Ethmoid roof / Middle turbinate (commonly described as middle turbinate in MCQs).
 Inferior attachment: Inferior turbinate / maxilla
Clinical importance:
Forms medial wall of the infundibulum
Key landmark in FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery)
Obstruction → Chronic sinusitis

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. The fiberoptic laryngoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vocal nodule
The swollen area in the given image and the clinical scenario is suggestive of vocal nodules. Vocal nodules are also known as singer’s or screamer’s nodes. It is present at the junction of anterior one-third with the posterior two thirds. It is the area of maximum vibration of the cord and thus is subjected to maximum trauma. Vocal nodules occur due to vocal trauma when person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities. They mostly affect teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.

questions.text: A patient having respiratory distress cannot be intubated, Next step will be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cricothyrotomy
Sol:  
Patient in respiratory distress
Cannot be intubated 
Emergency airway of choice:
• Cricothyrotomy (Emergency front-of-neck access)
• Quickest and life-saving in cannot intubate, cannot ventilate situations
• Provides definitive oxygenation until formal tracheostomy if required

questions.text: 75 yrs old patient complaining of hearing loss, on examination it was high frequency loss, Patient also give history of worsening of symptoms in noisy surrounding. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Presbycusis
Sol:  
Features of Presbycusis:
• Bilateral, symmetrical, progressive SNHL
• High frequencies lost first
• Difficulty in speech discrimination especially in noisy environments
• Pathology: Degeneration of hair cells at the basal turn of cochlea (affecting high frequencies)

questions.text: Patient with history of ear discharge and perforation presents with swelling in front of pinna as shown in the image. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Luc’s Abscess
Sol:  
• Luc’s Abscess
Definition: Subperiosteal abscess anterior to the pinna due to spread of infection from the mastoid through the tympanomastoid suture (foramen of Huschke).
Location: Preauricular / zygomatic root region
Etiology: Complication of CSOM

Other Options Explained:

• Zygomatic abscess:

Swelling above and lateral to the orbit/zygoma, not preauricular

• Bezold’s abscess:
Mastoid infection breaks through medial mastoid tip → Neck abscess in digastric triangle

• Citelli’s abscess:
Mastoid infection spreads to occipital / posterior neck area via mastoid emissary vein

questions.text: Narrowest part of Larynx in adult
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 Glottic
Sol:  
In adults, the narrowest part of the larynx is at the glottic level, specifically at the rima glottidis (the space between the true vocal cords).
In contrast, in infants and children, the subglottic region (below the vocal cords) is the narrowest part.
 Clinical Relevance:
Glottic narrowing affects voice and breathing (e.g., vocal cord paralysis, laryngeal edema).
Understanding the narrowest area is important during intubation and airway management.

questions.text: What is the function the marked area as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prevention of aspiration
Sol:  
Role of the Cuff in a Tracheostomy Tube: 
The cuff is an inflatable balloon located near the distal end of some tracheostomy tubes. Functions of the Cuff: 
1. Prevents Aspiration: The cuff seals the airway, reducing the risk of saliva, gastric contents, or secretions entering the lungs. 
2. Ensures Effective Positive Pressure Ventilation: In mechanically ventilated patients, the cuff prevents air from leaking around the tube, allowing full delivery of ventilatory support. 
3. Stabilizes the Tube: Helps keep the tracheostomy tube in place, especially in restless or critically ill patients. 
4. Improves Oxygenation: By preventing air leak, it ensures accurate oxygen delivery.

questions.text: 5 yr old child present brought y his mother presents with hearing loss, mouth breathing and poor school performance. Choose the expected hearing loss in the child
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conductive deafness
Sol:  
• These features are classically associated with adenoid hypertrophy and otitis media with effusion (OME), which commonly cause conductive hearing loss. 
• Mouth breathing results from nasal obstruction by enlarged adenoids. 
• Eustachian tube dysfunction due to adenoids leads to fluid accumulation in the middle ear (OME). 
• This fluid impairs sound conduction, leading to conductive hearing loss, which in turn affects speech and learning, causing poor school performance.

questions.text: A male patient presents with nasal obstruction, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and loss of smell. Endoscopic findings are shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atrophic rhinitis
Clinically patients present with nasal obstruction, foul odor, and merciful anosmia. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose. On examination of the nose, greenish or greyish crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, atrophied nasal turbinates, and epistaxis following the removal of the crusts. The roomy nasal cavity is seen due to the resorption of bones of the turbinates.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea. Investigations revealed that his HbA1C is 10%. The likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Malignant otitis externa
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea indicates malignant otitis externa. It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

choices.text: Patient will present with an inspiratory stridor
It is the most common congenital cause of stridor in children

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about laryngomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stridor improves in supine position
In laryngomalacia, stridor improves in prone position. Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Laryngocele
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

questions.text: Identify the sinus marked in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Maxillary sinus 
The sinus marked in the non-contrast CT image is the maxillary sinus.
Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities in that are present in the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:
Anterior group: It includes,
• Maxillary sinus(Antrum of highmore)
• Frontal sinus
• Anterior ethmoidal
All of the above sinuses open in the middle meatus and their ostia lie anterior to basal lamella of middle turbinate.

questions.text: A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X­ ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Esophagoscopy 
The clinical picture of the child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given x-rays are suggestive of a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin/disc battery.
The given x-rays are anteroposterior and lateral views of the chest and neck. Coins, disk batteries, and small toy items are commonly ingested by children.
The flat surface of a coin in the esophagus is seen on the anteroposterior view (AP view) i.e; they are oriented in the coronal plane. The edge is seen on the lateral view. Coins lying in the esophagus tend to lie in the coronal plane, whereas coins lying in the trachea lie in the sagittal plane.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Myringitis bullosa 
• The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and the otoscopic finding is suggestive of myringitis bullosa.
• Myringitis bullosa is characterized by painful hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. It occurs due to infection by a virus or mycoplasma.
• Option B: Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft.
• Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Linear acceleration 
The function of utricle and saccule is linear acceleration.
Utricle and saccule which contain sensory epithelium called macula that are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.
The ampullated end of each semicircular canal contains a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium called crista ampullaris that respond to angular acceleration and deceleration.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the left posterior choanae. Which of the following is the most appropriate for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Surgical excision 
The most probable diagnosis is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision is the most appropriate step in its management.
Adolescent male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx points towards angiofibroma. The consistency of the tumor is firm but the digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, because of the risk of profuse bleeding.
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head with contrast enhancement is now the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic smoking presented to the OPD with unilateral mild recurrent epistaxis, headache, hoarse voice, cough, and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, the patient has palpable cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
1.  Genetic. Chinese have a higher genetic susceptibility to nasopharyngeal cancer.
2. Viral. Epstein–Barr (EB) virus is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
3. Environmental. Air pollution, smoking of tobacco and opium, nitrosamines from dry salted fish, and smoke from burning of incense and wood have all been incriminated.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infections is most likely seen in the Maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aspergilloma
The usual causative organisms are Aspergillus niger, A. fumigatus or A. flavus. They invade nasal tissues when the host’s defense mechanisms are compromised due to immune-suppressive drugs.
Clinical features are those of acute or subacute rhinitis or sinusitis. A black or greyish membrane is seen in the nasal mucosa. Exploration of maxillary sinus reveals a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material. The organisms can be seen on special staining for fungus.

questions.text: A patient following an RTA presented with otorrhea has shown presentation below. The diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Halo sign
The patient most likely has a Basal skull fracture. It should be considered in all patients with head injuries, especially those with physical signs such as otorrhea, Battle sign or periorbital ecchymoses. The halo or double-ring sign is a classic image in medicine and was taught as a method for determining whether bloody discharge from the ears or nose contained cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rhinophyma
The image shows a Potato Nose. It occurs because of hypertrophy of the sebaceous gland and this condition is called Rhinophyma.
 It is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea. It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation; mostly affects men past middle age.

questions.text: True about BERA:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Used for SNHL
•BERA is used for Sensory Neuron Hearing Loss.
•The Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is an objective neurophysiological method for the evaluation of the hearing threshold and diagnosing retro-cochlear lesions. 
The aim of the study was to investigate the hearing level in children with suspected hearing loss or pathological speech development.
•IOC of choice for screening is Otoacoustic Emission.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Atrophic rhinitis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Young's operation
• Young’s operation is a surgery designed for the treatment of Atrophic rhinitis.
•The surgical procedure involves closure of the nasal cavity affected with atrophic rhinitis by creating mucocutaneous flaps. These flaps are sutured
together in two layers: first the mucosal layer, then the skin layer.
 Nasal steroid spray and Immunotherapy are used in Allergic rhinitis also known atrophic rhinitis.

questions.text: The maneuver in the image represents:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cottles maneuver
•Cottles maneuver is used to assess the patency of the internal nasal valve which is bounded by the septum medially, superiorly by the lower border of the upper lateral cartilage, and inferiorly by the head of the inferior turbinate.
Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV. Semont’s maneuver is a rehabilitation maneuver for patients with BPPV.
